p: Frankincense, an oleogum resin from trees of the genus Boswellia Roxb. ex Colebr. of the Burseraceae family, is widely used in traditional Arab, African, Ayurvedic, and Chinese medicines to treat various ailments including fever, pain, and swelling [ 1, 2, 3, 4]. Several clinical trials provided some evidence for potential therapeutic efficacy of frankincense in asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohnâ€™s disease, osteoarthritis, and collagenous colitis [ 5]. Moreover, several pilot studies indicate possible benefits of Boswellia extract treatment in cancer patients [ 6]. Hence, identification of biologically active compounds from Boswellia oleogum resins would facilitate their rational exploration for therapeutic applications.
